title: For a Safer Bet in a Tough Luxury Market, Consider the Penthouse
text:
Manhattan is a city chock full of awe-inspiring real estate. From the modern skyscrapers that tower over midtown, to the pre-war classics that preside over Central Park West.



But regardless of the building, no single residence is more coveted than the penthouse.



More: Paul Allen’s 414-Foot Yacht Octopus Lists for Over $300 Million

Owning a penthouse in Manhattan undoubtedly comes with prestige and massive price tags, but the purchase is more than just a trophy home. Penthouses can actually be more resilient investments in a market that’s been struggling, especially at the highest end.



During the first half of this year, New York’s luxury market—defined as homes priced above $5 million—was characterized by dipping prices, falling sales and oversupply, Mansion Global previously reported.



Data collected by Compass for Mansion Global, found that average sale prices for homes with a penthouse designation in Manhattan have been increasing at a sharper rate than typical condos and co-ops.



Between 2017 and 2018, the brokerage’s data showed that penthouse units sold in Manhattan saw their average prices increase 21%, from $7.68 million to $9.3 million.



In comparison, data available online from real estate consultant City Realty showed that over the same time, the average sale price for a co-op in Manhattan saw its value increase just 2.1%, while condo prices fell 4.59%.



But crucial to making your penthouse investment as resilient as possible is making sure it’s unique.



What Makes a Penthouse



A true penthouse “should stand out in terms of finishes, quality and amenities more than any of the other homes [in the building],” said Brian K. Lewis, a Manhattan-based broker with Compass.



One $42.5 million penthouse on the market at 565 Broome in SoHo, for example, comes complete with a private pool on one of the home’s terraces. Another, also asking $42.5 million, at 293 Lafayette St. in Nolita, has a wine room and a putting green.



More: Movie Producer Will List Pacific Palisades Home for $16.9 Million

Though a penthouse doesn’t necessarily have to have outdoor space, consumers have come to expect that as part of the prize of ownership, he said.



A penthouse is also expected to offer more square footage than the lowlier units in the building and impressive views—whether city, river or park—are de rigueur.



“A consumer that wants to have something special and they want to have the ultimate home in the building, they should make sure that the penthouse they’re attracted to is indeed rightfully named a penthouse and deserves to be called that,” Mr. Lewis said.



A Unique Investment



Though it's common to think of a penthouse as singular crown on top of a building, the designation is brandished around more and more commonly. According to StreetEasy, at 56 Leonard in Tribeca—a building dubbed the Jenga Building due to its offset floors—there are 10 penthouses, and at 30 Park Place, also in Tribeca, there are four penthouses on the market currently.



“Everyone and their brother in my industry calls everything on the top floor a penthouse, but that's just marketing,” Mr. Lewis said. “There are some big buildings that have seven, eight or nine penthouses,” but that simply waters down a penthouse’s rarity, he added.



And it’s exactly that distinctiveness which helps to make a penthouse investment less turbulent than other real estate in the city.



From Penta: Jazz Legend Miles Davis’ Trumpet Hits Auction at Christie’s

“What makes a true penthouses is that it’s unique,” said Jonathan Miller, chief executive of real estate appraisal firm Miller Samuel. “Apartments that are unique tend to be less volatile.”



“It’s the principle of scarcity, to use appraisal speak,” he said. “It doesn't prevent [a penthouse] from seeing declines or challenges; they’re not immune to negative market trends.”



“We’re talking about probabilities rather than guarantees, having a unique asset—in a favorable way—reduces risk,” Mr. Miller said.



Though not infallible, penthouses are more immune to wider market conditions, according to Leonard Steinberg, chief evangelist and broker at Compass.



“The penthouse is the cherry on top of the cake. Some people don't like cherries, but nobody has a dream about living in the middle of the building,” Mr. Steinberg said. “It’s a romantic fantasy, a penthouse in Manhattan is a collector’s item.”



“If you have a collector’s item, chances are, it's going to hold its value better than everything else. If it’s an escalating market, your profit [on a penthouse] will be above other apartments,” and on the other hand, during a downturn, it’ll devalue less than other apartments, he said.



And there will always be a very captivated market, too, according to Mr. Steinberg.



More: The Irish Ancestral Home of the Guinness Family Feels Like a Small Castle

Take 520 Park Avenue, for example, a new development on the Upper East Side. The tower is becoming one of the most exclusive condominiums in Manhattan as its big-ticket closings gradually reveal the host of high-net worth individuals investing in the building’s multiple penthouse units. Buyers reportedly include investment banker Ken Moelis and British billionaire inventor James Dyson along with former Barclays CEO Bob Diamond.



“People with money are always looking for things with scarcity—it’s the ultimate driving force of valuation,” Mr. Steinberg told Mansion Global.



“When supply is limited, it boosts desirability, then you have to pay up if you want it,” he said. “The person who has a property that is very difficult to replicate is always in a good position.”
